claim: The name of a mythical creature is also the name of a Small Solar System body.

supporting.text: The name 'Centaur' refers to both a mythical creature and a class of small Solar System bodies that exhibit characteristics of both asteroids and comets.

attacks.text: The name 'Centaur' refers to both a mythical creature and a class of small Solar System bodies that exhibit characteristics of both asteroids and comets.
The term 'Centaur' is not universally recognized as a name for small Solar System bodies outside astronomical circles, limiting its general validity.
Astronomical nomenclature officially classifies Centaurs as a distinct group of small Solar System bodies, documented by the International Astronomical Union.
Some Centaurs are reclassified as comets or asteroids upon further study, undermining the stability of the category.
Dynamical and physical studies consistently differentiate Centaurs from other small bodies, preserving their classification despite reclassifications of individual objects.

supporting.text: The name 'Phoenix' is associated with a mythical bird and has been used to name asteroids, such as 4543 Phoenix.

attacks.text: The name 'Phoenix' is associated with a mythical bird and has been used to name asteroids, such as 4543 Phoenix.
Not all names of mythical creatures are used for Small Solar System bodies, making this a selective example.
Many mythical creature names are indeed used for asteroids, comets, or other celestial bodies, supporting the claim's generality.
The name 'Phoenix' is also used for non-mythological entities (e.g., cities, companies), weakening its exclusive mythical association.
In astronomical naming conventions, 'Phoenix' is explicitly linked to the mythical bird, not other uses.

supporting.text: The name 'Dragon' is linked to a mythical creature and has been used for asteroids like 2002 DR3, informally known as 'Dragon'.

attacks.text: The name 'Dragon' is linked to a mythical creature and has been used for asteroids like 2002 DR3, informally known as 'Dragon'.
The informal name 'Dragon' for asteroid 2002 DR3 is not officially recognized by the International Astronomical Union (IAU).
Informal names are widely used in astronomical communities despite lacking IAU recognition, and their usage is still valid in context.
The term 'Dragon' is not exclusive to mythical creatures; it also refers to a SpaceX spacecraft, which may cause confusion.
The context of the claim clearly refers to mythical creatures and Small Solar System bodies, not spacecraft.

supporting.text: The name 'Pegasus' refers to a mythical winged horse and is also the name of an asteroid, 33000 Pegasus.

attacks.text: The name 'Pegasus' refers to a mythical winged horse and is also the name of an asteroid, 33000 Pegasus.
Not all mythical creatures have corresponding Small Solar System bodies named after them, making this a rare case.
Many asteroids are named after mythical creatures, such as 433 Eros (named after the Greek god of love) and 1036 Ganymed (named after the cupbearer of the gods).
The naming conventions for Small Solar System bodies are not strictly limited to mythical creatures, reducing the uniqueness of the claim.

supporting.text: The name 'Cyclops' is associated with a mythical one-eyed giant and has been used for asteroids like 1916 Boreas, which was initially nicknamed 'Cyclops'.

attacks.text: The name 'Cyclops' is associated with a mythical one-eyed giant and has been used for asteroids like 1916 Boreas, which was initially nicknamed 'Cyclops'.
1916 Boreas is not officially named 'Cyclops'—it was only an informal nickname, so it doesn't count as a formal naming overlap.
Informal nicknames are still culturally recognized and often precede official naming, so the connection is valid.
The name 'Cyclops' is not officially assigned to any Small Solar System Body in the IAU database, weakening the argument.
The IAU naming conventions allow for mythological names, and historical nicknames reflect real usage even if unofficial.
